text: Research Abstract: This research is concerned with studying: (Quranic Objectives in Surah 'Qaf'), relying on the inductive and deductive method. Its importance lies in the virtue of Surah (Qaf) and its great status among the Quranic chapters. Yet, it has not received its due share in studies addressing Quranic objectives, despite its importance in understanding and reflecting upon the Quran. The research aims to derive the Quranic objectives from Surah (Qaf), identify the core issues addressed by the Surah, and understand the secret behind the Prophet's (peace be upon him) recitation of this Surah in large gatherings. This research consists of an introduction, three sections, and a conclusion: The first section is dedicated to defining the science of Quranic Objectives and explaining its importance. The second section is an introductory preface to Surah (Qaf), mentioning aspects that help reveal the Quranic objectives. The third section (which is the core of the research) mentions the objective of the Surah in general with supporting evidence, then its sub-themes, followed by a detailed objective-based reflection (Tadabbur) on the Surah's verses. The research concluded that Surah (Qaf) addressed several main topics regarding Islamic creed; establishing the fundamentals of religion such as belief in Allah, His angels, His books, His messengers, the Last Day, and Destiny, and providing a complete conception of human life,

text: In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. Introduction: Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and peace and blessings be upon the most noble of prophets and messengers. To proceed: The Holy Quran is the clear light, the evident truth, Allah's firm rope, and His straight path. Allah sent it down to His servants to be a methodology for life and a beacon for guidance. He commanded them to adhere to it, understand it, reflect upon it, extract its treasures, stir up its buried gems, reveal its truths, and stand upon its noble goals that guarantee the interests of the servants in their livelihood and their hereafter, and lead them to the path of righteousness. From this standpoint came this research titled: (Quranic Objectives in Surah Qaf), to aid the reader in reflecting upon the words of Allah Almighty. Importance of the Research: • First, the importance of the research stems from the virtue of the Surah dealt with in the research. The Prophet (peace be upon him) used to recite Surah (Qaf) in great gatherings and persisted in doing so as a reminder of the fundamentals of faith and creed it contains, acting upon the saying of Allah Almighty: {So remind by the Qur'an whoever fears My threat}. • Second, the research derives its value from the importance of the science of Quranic Objectives and its role in understanding and reflecting upon the Quran in the optimal way.

text: • Finally: The importance of the research increases due to the lack of independent research and studies on Quranic objectives in this specific Surah, and the scarcity of writing in the field of Quranic objectives in general, despite the scientific awakening in the field of the science of Maqasid (Objectives). Research Objectives: The research aims to care for Quranic guidance and what the Quran was revealed for, to derive the Quranic objectives contained in Surah (Qaf), to know the core issues addressed by the Surah, and to understand the secret behind the Prophet's (peace be upon him) recitation of this Surah in large gatherings. The research also aims to highlight the eloquence and inimitability of the Holy Quran through the study of Quranic objectives, understanding their importance, and contributing to their development. Previous Studies: • Ancient and modern books of Tafsir (exegesis) are not devoid of Quranic objectives, though they vary in the extent and significance of their attention to them; however, they are mostly scattered in various places in their books. Ibn al-Qayyim has precious words about Surah (Qaf) with which he opened his book: (Al-Fawaid), and I singled him out for mention because it is not in a place one would typically look for exegesis. • Some academic papers and theses have been written on Quranic objectives in general or on a specific Surah (other than Surah Qaf), including: • Quranic Objectives: A Methodological Study, Dr. Muhammad bin Abdullah Al-Rabiah, Journal of Imam Al-Shatibi Institute for Quranic Studies, Issue 27, (pp. 207-262). The research addressed the subject of Quranic objectives from both theoretical and practical aspects,

There is no doubt that Objectives are different from Tafsir. Objectives are concerned with mentioning the general purpose of the Surah, linking the sections of the Surah to one another, then the Objective-based Reflection on the verses by mentioning the direct intent of the verse, aided by the objective of the Surah, then expressing the verse in an objective-oriented style, then mentioning the guidance of the verses; which is the most important intent, as pointed out by Dr. Muhammad Al-Rabiah (1). This research is but an attempt to apply this methodology, hoping it will benefit researchers and those working in the field of Quranic Objectives, which still suffers from ambiguity of concept and instability of methodology. Although this research shares some issues and details with previous studies, it differs from them in terms of its subject or the method of addressing Quranic objectives, as this research deals with Quranic objectives in Surah (Qaf) specifically, and using the methodology mentioned earlier. I ask Allah to grant me success in what He loves and is pleased with, and to grant us sincerity in word and deed. text: Section One: The Science of Quranic Objectives. First Demand: Definition of Quranic Objectives. • First: Defining it as a descriptive compound: 1 - Maqasid (Objectives) linguistically: Plural of 'Maqsad', which is a mim-infinitive derived from the verb (Qasada). Ibn Faris (d. 395 AH) said: "The Qaf, Sad, and Dal are three origins: One indicates coming to something and aiming for it; the other indicates filling/packing into something. The origin is: 'Qasadtu-hu qasdan wa maqsadan' (I aimed for it). From this root: 'Aqsada-hu al-sahm' (The arrow hit him directly), meaning it hit him and killed him on the spot, as if it was said because it did not swerve from him... And from it: 'Aqsadat-hu hayyah' (A snake killed him). The other origin: 'Qasadtu al-shay'' (I broke the thing). And 'Al-Qasdah' is a piece of something when it is broken, plural 'Qasad'. [And from it 'Qasad'] of spears. And 'Rumh qasid', and it has 'inqasad' (broken). The third origin: 'Al-Naqah al-Qasid': The camel packed and filled with meat... Therefore, the poem (Qasidah) was named Qasidah because of the perfection/trimming of its verses, and its verses are only of complete structures" (1). In the language, it has multiple meanings: including straightness of the road, justice, reliance and aiming, coming to a thing, moderation/middle course, and breaking (2). "Ibn Jinni said: The origin of the material (Q S D) and its occurrences in the speech of the Arabs is: determination, orientation, rising, and moving towards a thing, whether with moderation or deviation" (3).

text: And the intent (Maqsad) of speech: It is that the speech and utterance are directed towards a specific meaning or end that the speaker desires (1). 2 - And the Quran linguistically: A source like 'Ghufran' from 'Qara'a': 1 - Meaning (Tala - recited), in the sense of a passive participle; i.e., meaning recited. 2 - Or meaning (Jama'a - gathered). According to the first meaning (recited), it is a verbal noun (Masdar). In Sharia: It is "The miraculous speech revealed to the Prophet (peace be upon him), written in the Mushafs, transmitted via Tawatur (successive narration), whose recitation is an act of worship" (3). • Second: Defining it as a proper name for a specific art: Quranic Objectives: These are the ends that Allah Almighty intended in His Book, or it is (The intent of Allah Almighty from His speech) (4). Dr. Abdul Karim Hamidi defined them as: "The ends for which the Quran was revealed to achieve the interests of the servants" (5). Quranic Objectives can be defined as "The original meanings for whose explanation and realization the Quran was revealed," and we can express non-objectives as secondary meanings. Asserting that this is Allah's intent from His speech - despite its difficulty or impossibility - might be thought of as containing some bad manners with Allah Almighty, and Allah knows best. The importance of Quranic Objectives is highlighted by the fact that they are the key to Tadabbur (reflection), and reflection is the intended goal of revealing the Quran. Allah Almighty said: {[This is] a blessed Book which We have revealed to you, [O Muhammad], that they might reflect upon its verses} [Sad: 29]. Allah Almighty condemned the polytheists who do not reflect upon the Quran nor understand it; Allah Almighty said: {So what is [the matter] with those people that they can hardly understand any statement?} [An-Nisa: 78], and He said: {Then do they not reflect upon the Qur'an, or are there locks upon [their] hearts?} [Muhammad: 24]. The Imam of Maqasid, Al-Shatibi, may Allah have mercy on him (d. 790 AH), decided that this condemnation is because they do not understand Allah's intent from the address, not that they do not understand the speech itself; because that is impossible, for they are Arabs, and the Quran was revealed in their tongue, so they know the speech according to their Arabic nature. But there is a difference between the apparent meaning and the intent behind it. Then he said: "So reflection is only for one who turns to the objectives, and that is apparent in that they turned away from the objectives of the Quran; so reflection did not occur from them" (2). End quote. The science of Quranic Objectives is capable of regulating the methodology of dealing with the Quran as a text revealed for a specific purpose, so its topics are understood in its light; because knowing the speaker's objective affects the understanding of the text of the speech. regulating this universal objective has its effect

text: Section Two: Introduction to Surah 'Qaf'. First Demand: The Surah's Name, Number of Verses, and Stage of Revelation. * First Issue: The Name of the Surah (1): It was named Surah (Qaf) in the era of the Companions; because it opens with the spelling letter (Qaf), like Surah (Ta-Ha), (Ya-Sin), and (Sad). It is a Tawqifi name (divinely ordained); because established Hadiths and traditions have been reported regarding that (2). Among them is what Ubaidullah bin Abdullah bin Utbah bin Masoud narrated: That Umar bin Al-Khattab asked Abu Waqid Al-Laithi: What did the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) use to recite in [Eid] Al-Adha and Al-Fitr? He said: He used to recite in them {Qaf. By the honored Qur'an} and {The Hour has come near, and the moon has split} [Al-Qamar: 1], [Narrated by Muslim] (3). It was also named Surah (Al-Basiqat), because of its mention in His saying: {And tall [basiqat] palm trees having fruit arranged in layers} [Qaf: 10], and this is an Ijtihadi name (based on reasoning); because it was not reported in a Hadith or tradition, but rather it is from the naming of some exegetes (4). * Second Issue: Number of its verses, words, and letters (5): Scholars agreed that the number of its verses is forty-five (45) verses, wherein (Qaf) is not counted as an independent

Fourth Demand: Correlations (Munisabat) in Surah 'Qaf'. * First Issue: Correlation of the Surah's beginning with its end (3): Surah (Qaf) began with the mention of the Quran {Qaf. By the honored Qur'an}, and ended with it {So remind by the Qur'an whoever fears My threat}. Likewise, it began with the mention of Resurrection in His saying: {When we have died and become dust? That is a distant return}, and ended with it in His saying: {The Day the earth splits open from them, hastening forth. That is a gathering easy for Us}. Likewise, the mention of the heavens and earth and what is between them in the beginning of the Surah: {Have they not looked at the heaven above them - how We structured it and adorned it and [how] it has no rifts?...} verses, and He said at its end: {And We did certainly create the heavens and earth and what is between them in six days, and there touched Us no weariness}.

text: * Second Issue: Correlation of the Surah with what precedes it (Surah Al-Hujurat): Scholars have paid attention to explaining the correlations between Surahs, which is largely an Ijtihadi (interpretative) matter, hence their opinions varied: Imam Abu Hayyan Al-Andalusi (d. 745 AH) said: "Its correlation to the end of what preceded it, is that He, the Exalted, informed that those who said: {We have believed} [Al-Hujurat: 14], their faith was not true. The negation of their faith is evidence of denying the Prophethood of the Messenger (peace be upon him), so He said: {But they wonder that there has come to them a warner} [Qaf: 2]. Lack of faith also indicates denial of Resurrection, so He followed it with that" (1). Al-Biqa'i (d. 885 AH) said: "Its intent (i.e., Surah Qaf) is to indicate the encompassing Power, which is the result of what Al-Hujurat ended with, concerning encompassing Knowledge, to explain that there must be a Resurrection for the Day of Threat" (2). Al-Tabarsi (d. 548 AH) said: "When Allah concluded that Surah by mentioning faith and its conditions for the servants, He opened this Surah by mentioning what must be believed regarding the Quran and evidences of Tawheed" (3). * Third Issue: Correlation of the Surah with what follows it (Surah Al-Dhariyat): He mentioned in Surah (Qaf) Resurrection, Recompense, Paradise, and Hell, and opened Surah Al-Dhariyat by swearing that what they were promised of that is true and that Recompense is real. He mentioned in Surah (Qaf) the destruction of many generations in general terms, and mentioned that in detail in Surah Al-Dhariyat (4).

text: * Fourth Issue: Correlation between Surah (Qaf) and what precedes it in terms of Revelation (Surah Al-Mursalat): Surah Al-Mursalat addresses the subject of deniers of the Day of Judgment through encouragement and intimidation. Surah (Qaf) continues the subject of addressing deniers of the Day of Judgment with another style. These intellectual and psychological remedies contained in Surah (Qaf) are complementary treatments to what came in Surah Al-Mursalat, not identical repetition. Surah (Qaf) adds to it the addressing of those who deny the message of Muhammad (peace be upon him) on the pretext that he is a human from among them, and treating the soul of the Messenger (peace be upon him) and stabilizing his heart against the denial he met from his people and the hurtful words they confronted him with (1). * Fifth Issue: Correlation between Surah 'Qaf' and what follows it in terms of Revelation (Surah Al-Balad): The subject of Surah Al-Balad revolves around the trial which is the purpose of human creation, which logically entails obligation, responsibility, then accounting, deciding judgment, and realization of recompense. The Surah also clarifies some distractions of the soul from faith in the Day of Judgment. So Surah Al-Balad follows up on completing the persuasion regarding the Divine Law of Recompense, around which the subject of Surah Qaf revolved (2). * * *

text: Section Three: Objective-based Reflection on Surah (Qaf). First Demand: The Objective of the Surah. Surah (Qaf) addresses - like other Meccan Surahs - the subject of those who deny the message of Muhammad (peace be upon him), and what he brought regarding the news of Resurrection and Account, except that it is more manifest in addressing the Resurrection (1). Al-Biqa'i (d. 885 AH) said: "Its intent is confirming the Prophet (peace be upon him) in the Message, the bulk of which is warning, and the greatest of which is informing about the Day of Coming Out" (2). • Proofs of the Objective: 1 - An explicit verse on the objective: Allah Almighty said: {Qaf. By the honored Qur'an (1) But they wonder that there has come to them a warner from among themselves, and the disbelievers say, "This is an amazing thing. (2) When we have died and become dust? That is a distant return}. The transitional strike (Idrab) from swearing by the Quran to presenting the disbelievers' statement in denying Prophethood and denying the Return indicates the importance of what is transitioned to, and that it is the axis of the speech. 2 - Correlation of the Surah's opening with its conclusion: That the Surah opened with an oath by the Quran, then presented the polytheists' doubt in denying Resurrection, then followed the doubt by establishing Allah's power through cosmic signs and destroying deniers, and concluded likewise by establishing the occurrence of Resurrection, and the command to remind by the Quran. Thus clarifying that the miraculous Quran is among the clearest proofs of Resurrection, and that reflection on the Quran is among the greatest ways leading to knowing the truth.

Surah Al-Mursalat addressed the subject of deniers of the Day of Judgment with encouragement and intimidation. Then Surah Al-Dhariyat followed it, explaining Allah's wisdom in creating man after emphasizing Allah's great power. 6 - Its Virtues (4): The Prophet (peace be upon him) persisted in reciting it in large forums and great gatherings, which indicates its inclusion of the foundations of Islamic creed, most importantly: Belief in Resurrection and the Return. 7 - Its Topics: Surah (Qaf) addressed a number of issues of Islamic creed, and all of them lead back to the issue of Resurrection after death. Their explanation will come in the next demand.

text: Third Demand: Segments of the Surah. Surah (Qaf) can be divided according to its objective into three main segments: • First Segment: From the beginning of the Surah to His saying: {Did We fail in the first creation? But they are in confusion over a new creation}: In it is the presentation of the polytheists' doubt, and refuting it by establishing the comprehensiveness of His knowledge and perfection of His power, and displaying some manifestations of His power from Allah's signs in the universe, and in destroying previous nations. • Second Segment: From His saying: {And We have already created man} to His saying 5: {They will have whatever they wish therein, and with Us is more} [Verses: 16-35]: In it is "Clarification of Allah's surveillance and hegemony over man which starts from his birth, passes through death, then ends with Resurrection and Account, then the destiny to Paradise or Hell." • Third Segment: From His saying: {And how many a generation We destroyed before them} to the end of the Surah [Verses: 36-45]: In it is consolation for the Messenger (peace be upon him), clarification of the reality of his message, threatening the polytheists, and establishing Resurrection. It can be said that most of it is confirmation of what was mentioned in the beginning of the Surah explicitly or implicitly in reverse order. In this is a denial against the deniers of Resurrection, and an accusation of their intellects being shallow and superficial, and "a mockery of them, declaring them foolish, and rebuking them" for their deeming Resurrection impossible (8).

book_title: The Quranic Objectives in Surah Qaf
text: * The Second Section [Verses: 16 - 35]: {And We have already created man and know what his soul whispers to him, and We are closer to him than [his] jugular vein}: This verse is cited in clarifying some details of the first creation mentioned in the verse: {Did We fail in the first creation?}. In it is: "An alert to the greatest signs of Allah's power, evidences of His Lordship, and proofs of the Return, which is the creation of man composed of flesh, bone, veins, nerves, ligaments, outlets, tools, knowledge, wills, and industries; all that from a drop of water" (1). And "An alert to the vastness of Allah's knowledge of all their conditions. If He knows the whisper of the soul; then there is no wonder that He knows what the earth consumes of them." In it is an indication that "whispering in the soul is sometimes from Satan and sometimes from the soul" (2), and that "parts of man veil other parts, but nothing veils Allah's knowledge" (3). In it is "a metonymy for warning against concealing what does not please Allah" (4), and "a deterrent from sins that are hidden" (5). "This is what invites man to be mindful of his Creator who is aware of his conscience and inner self, close to him in all his states, so he feels shy from Him seeing him where He forbade him, or missing him where He commanded him" (6).

book_title: The Quranic Objectives in Surah Qaf
text: {When the two receivers receive, seated on the right and on the left (17) Man does not utter any word except that with him is an observer prepared}: These two verses are cited in clarifying the constant surveillance over every human (1); in them is a severe warning, admonition, and threat of recompense for the polytheists who denied the Day of Resurrection out of rejection and arrogance. And "informing that on man's right and left are two angels writing his deeds and sayings, and drawing attention by counting sayings and writing them to the writing of deeds, which occur less frequently, and are greater in impact than sayings, and are the goals and ends of sayings" (2). So man should guard his tongue and limbs from bad deeds and desire good deeds. In this is a sufficient indication for the intelligent person that man is not left in vain, and that he was created for a majestic wisdom and a lofty purpose. The statement of His closeness - the Exalted - when the two angels receive man's sayings and deeds is "an indication that appointing the two angels as guardians is a matter He has no need of", and that this appointing is for a wisdom (3), which is establishing the proof against the servant on the Day of Resurrection (4). {And the intoxication of death will bring the truth; that is what you were trying to avoid}: This verse is a transition "to narrating what the deniers will face at the time of their death" (5). In it is the mention of "the Minor Resurrection, which is the intoxication of death, and that it comes with the truth, which is: meeting Him, Glory be to Him, coming to Him, presenting the soul to Him, and the reward and punishment hastened for it before the Great Resurrection" (6).

text: The use of the past tense is an alert that the matter is certain to occur, and that its like has actually occurred to those people whose death preceded the revelation of the text (1). In this is an awakening of hearts from heedlessness, and an emphasis that man should prepare for death and its conditions, and spend his life in apprehension and caution. {And the Horn will be blown. That is the Day of [carrying out] the threat}: This verse is cited in "mentioning the Great Resurrection" (2). In it is the news of the angel entrusted with blowing into the Horn blowing the second blow, which is the blow of Resurrection, and that is the day of punishment promised to the disbelievers and the disobedient. "He singled out the threat (Wa'id) for mention without the promise (Wa'd), to magnify the terror of this day and warn the disobedient of what will happen in it" (3), and to suit the strong style of the Surah in rebuke and reprimand. {And every soul will come, with it a driver and a witness}: This verse is cited in "narrating what the deniers will face when they are resurrected on the Day of Resurrection from the truths they used to evade or doubt" (4). In it is the news that "everyone will come to Allah, Glory be to Him, on that day with a driver driving him and a witness testifying against him. This is other than the testimony of his limbs, other than the testimony of the earth on which he was against him, and other than the testimony of His Messenger and the believers." In the verse is evidence that the Judge does not judge by His knowledge [alone]. "For Allah, Glory be to Him, calls to witness against the servant the guardians, the prophets, the places where they did good and evil, and the skins with which they disobeyed Him. He does not judge between them merely by His knowledge; while He is the Most Just of judges and the Wisest of rulers. For this reason, He informed His Prophet that he judges between people by what he hears of their acknowledgment and the testimony

(1). {You were heedless of this, so We have removed from you your cover, and your sight, this Day, is sharp}: This verse begins mentioning the Reckoning and its conditions. In it is a rebuke for the one negligent in deeds in the world, and a mention of what Allah Almighty says by way of sarcasm to man about his heedlessness in the world regarding the Hereafter, and lack of belief in it. "For He, Glory be to Him, informed that man is in heedlessness of this matter which deserves not to be neglected and to be constantly in his remembrance and mind... Then He informed that the cover of heedlessness and absentmindedness is removed from him on that day just as the cover of sleep is removed from the heart so it wakes up and from the eye so it opens. So the ratio of removing this cover from the servant upon witnessing is like the ratio of removing the cover of sleep from him upon waking up" (2). In the verse is a statement of the perfection of Allah's power through "His encompassing, Glory be to Him, of decreeing and incapacitating" (3), and also an affirmation of Prophethood in a marvelous style. The verse indicated the deficiency of the human intellect and its inability to perceive what benefits it and avoid what harms it, and its constant need for someone to guide it to the path of righteousness and guidance. For that reason, Allah sent messengers, revealed books, and called to belief in the Unseen which our senses do not perceive nor our minds reach in this world. "So when we die, the Unseen becomes seen, and we witness what the messengers informed about, which was Unseen to us" (4); as this verse informed.

book_title: The Quranic Objectives in Surah Qaf
text: {And his companion will say, "This is what I have ready"}: This verse is cited in mentioning the beginning of the Reckoning. In it is the news that man is brought by his companion entrusted with him from the angels, bringing with him his deed which he recorded, and presenting him for Reckoning before the Lord of the Worlds, in a terrifying situation that makes bodies shudder and hearts tremble. So man should prepare to meet Allah before death, and call himself to account before he is called to account in the Hereafter. {Throw into Hell every obstinate disbeliever (24) Preventer of good, aggressor, and doubter (25) Who made [as equal] with Allah another deity; then throw him into the severe punishment}: These verses are cited in presenting scenes from the difficult, terrifying situation in the trial of criminals and stating their fate, and the general command to throw them into Hell. In it is a rebuke to the disbelievers, warning them, arousing fear in them, and driving them to determent. "The verse in its absoluteness and generality includes declaring the prevention of good and aggression as ugly in general. And warning the one characterized by these morals of Allah's wrath and anger..., and includes affirming that what the disbelieving, good-preventing, aggressive, malicious ones encounter is only a recompense for the sin they committed, rightfully and justly" (1). In it is what emphasizes that it is not permissible to punish a person without trial or without proving his crimes. {His companion said, "Our Lord, I did not make him transgress, but he was in extreme error"}: This verse is regarding the dispute of the disbeliever and his companion from the devils. For when the disbeliever arrives at the Fire, he wants to evade his disbelief and stubbornness by casting the blame on his companion who used to beautify disbelief for him. So his companion disavows bearing the consequence of man's disbelief. And "of the witty wisdom in that is arousing fear in the disbelievers, the misguided, and the criminals, and driving them to refrain by notifying them that those who whispered to them from their companions and devils will disavow them, and that those accompanying them from the angels of

text: Allah have recorded everything against them and will present it to Allah Almighty to hold them accountable" (1). This disavowal and dispute is proof of the horror of the situation. {He said, "Do not dispute before Me, while I had already presented to you the threat (28) The word will not be changed with Me, and never will I be unjust to the servants"}: These two verses are cited in clarifying the perfection of Allah's knowledge and the perfection of His justice; for "the perfection of His knowledge and awareness prevents changing the word before Him and promoting falsehood to Him; and the perfection of His justice and richness prevents His injustice to His servants" (2). Since Allah, Glory be to Him, clarified the threat in the world on the tongues of His messengers; no confusion or argument remained for anyone. So there is no benefit in disputing to cast the blame of disbelief on one of the two parties, because the equality of the two parties in disbelief is sufficient to hold all accountable equally. In the verse is "an establishment of the meaning of injustice in the souls of the nation; for it is not permissible to punish the offender before legislating the law, just as Allah did not punish His servants except after prior warning, despite Him being the Creator of the servants, to Whom belongs the creation and the command, Doer of what He wills" (3). In it is a statement "that among possible matters is what constitutes injustice which Allah, Glory be to Him, is exalted above despite His power over it, and for that He is praised and extolled; for praise and extolment occur regarding optional matters of action and inaction" (4). {On the Day We will say to Hell, "Have you been filled?" and it will say, "Are there any more?"}: This verse is cited in "terrifying those driven to Hell that they should not hope that their large number will cramp the vastness of Hell so some of them might hope to be among those for whom no place is found in it. "The use of the present tense indicates that the question and answer are repeated and renewed after throwing group after group into Hell" (2). As mentioned in the agreed-upon Hadith: «Hell will continue to be thrown into, and it will say: 'Are there any more?', until the Lord of Glory places His Foot in it, so its parts will fold upon each other and it will say: 'Enough, enough, by Your Glory and Generosity'» (3). "In it is an indication that existing things yearn to fulfill and show compliance to what Allah created them for, and that they do not hesitate or make excuses in performing it" (4). {And Paradise will be brought near to the righteous, not far}: This verse, and the one following it, is "a digression to mentioning the lot of the believers on the Day of Resurrection - according to the custom of the Quran in following intimidation with encouragement and vice versa -" (5). In it is the mention of bringing Paradise near to the righteous, and a statement of the virtue of piety (Taqwa) and the honor of the righteous with the Lord of the Worlds. Which "is of a nature to attract those with conscious hearts and good souls, and carry them to walk on the straight path, and spread tranquility, bliss, and contentment in them" (6). In it is an invitation to the polytheists to believe and choose piety, and leave what they are in of denial and heedlessness. {This is what you were promised - for every returner [to Allah] and keeper [of His covenant]}: This verse is cited in clarifying what is said to the righteous when Paradise is brought near to them, and mentioning two of their attributes, which are being a returner (Awwab) and a keeper (Hafiz).

text: In it is an indication that it behooves the believer to maintain obedience and keep Allah's commandments and limits. If a slip occurs from him, he follows it with repentance and returns to his Lord. "It is not enough for a person to declare his Islam, rather he must strive in fearing Allah through righteous deeds and avoiding sins, and be a keeper of his covenants and duties, watchful of Allah in his secret and public, turning to Him with his heart and limbs. In this there is the intent of refining the Muslim's soul and preparing him to be righteous, dutiful, good, guided, with an alert heart, pure conscience and soul, performing his duties towards Allah and people for their own sake, fearing his Lord in secret and public" (1). {Who feared the Most Merciful unseen and came with a heart returning [in repentance]}: This verse is cited in mentioning the third and fourth attributes of the righteous, which is that they fear Him, the Exalted, in secret, despite their knowledge of His vast mercy, and they return from disobeying Allah and approach His obedience, and do not nullify their righteous deed at the end of their lives, so they come on the Day of Resurrection returning [in repentance]. In this is confirmation that "beneficial fear is fearing Him, the Exalted, in the unseen and the seen" (2), and that it is one of the causes of a good ending. In describing Him, the Exalted, with Mercy, and describing the heart with Returning (Inabah), is an invitation to the polytheists and kindness to the disobedient not to despair of Allah's mercy and "not to despair of the acceptance of repentance because of the abundance of threats driven to them, following the custom of the Quran in following intimidation with encouragement and vice versa" (3). In coupling the name Al-Rahman (The Most Merciful) with fear (Khashyah), is an alert that the knowledge of the righteous of the vastness of His mercy, the Exalted, does not prevent them from fearing Him, and that their fear "is accompanied by intimacy

In this is confirmation of Allah's justice, His majestic wisdom, and the perfection of His power, and evidence of the legitimacy of frightening the disobedient and deniers with divine punishment (3), and taking lessons from Allah's Sunnah in the collective destruction of nations. {Indeed in that is a reminder for whoever has a heart or who listens while he is present [in mind]}: This verse is cited in urging reflection on the Quran, and "thinking about considering the conditions that caused the destruction of previous nations; so they measure their conditions against them" (4). In it is: praising the status of the believers and alluding to likening the polytheists to one who has no heart and one who does not listen because they are far from benefiting from reminders (5). In it is "declaring Allah, Glory be to Him, free from weariness (Lughub). Declaring free (Tanzih) implies His description, Glory be to Him, with attributes of affirmative perfection, because negative matters are not perfection unless they imply positive matters. So negating weariness implies the perfection of His power, the Exalted, and the utmost strength, unlike the creature who is afflicted by fatigue and exhaustion as he is afflicted" (3). In it is "belying the enemies of Allah among the Jews where they said He rested on the seventh day" (4). In creating the heavens and earth in six days is "teaching man deliberateness and gradation" (5), "and had He willed, the Exalted, it would have been in less than the blink of an eye, but He enacted for us deliberateness in that" (6); Sa'id bin Jubayr said: "Allah Mighty and Majestic was capable of creating the heavens and earth in a glance and a moment, but He created them in six days to teach His creation verification and deliberateness in matters" (7).

text: The Exalted said: {So be patient over what they say and exalt [Allah] with praise of your Lord before the rising of the sun and before its setting (39) And [in part] of the night exalt Him and after prostration}: These two verses are cited in treating the psychological and spiritual state of the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, firstly, and for educating the bearers of the Messenger's message, peace and blessings be upon him, from the scholars and callers of his nation (1). In them is urging the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, to patience and clarifying what aids him in it of Tasbih (glorification) and Tahmid (praise) which prayer includes, and the command to "emulate Him, Glory be to Him, in patience over what His enemies say about Him, just as He, Glory be to Him, was patient over the saying of the Jews: that He rested! 'And no one is more patient over harm he hears than Him' (2)" (3). In the verse is indication that patience is acquired by practicing patience, and confirmation of the greatness of prayer and its effect in solving internal and external crises, and "that prayer is the greatest antidote for victory and removing worry, and for this reason the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to rush to prayer if a matter troubled him" (4). {And listen on the Day when the Caller will call out from a place that is near (41) The Day they will hear the blast in truth. That is the Day of Emergence}: These two verses are also cited in strengthening the heart of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. In them is "depicting the day of the polytheists' calamity and its proximity and explaining what is in it for them of exemplary punishments and catastrophic afflictions" (5), and reminding him, peace and blessings be upon him, of what will happen in the Hereafter of "the Caller calling for the return of souls to their bodies for gathering" (6) and emergence from the graves; because increasing certainty in the Hereafter

text: and renewing it is one of the greatest aids to patience. For with certainty the chest expands and derives great spiritual strength with which worldly hardships and worries diminish. In this is a spiritual instruction for callers to care for the remembrance of the Hereafter to be a help for the caller in his journey. {Indeed, it is We who give life and cause death, and to Us is the destination}: This verse is cited in affirming the doctrine of Resurrection after death. In it is the reminder that the Giver of Life and Causer of Death is Allah with no partner, and inferring from that the Resurrection which is the Greatest Giving of Life, because "the Return is not harder than the Beginning, so whoever acknowledges it and denies the Resurrection is stubbornly opposing or definitely insane" (1). "So whoever gave life first then caused death, there is no wonder that He returns the one He caused to die to another life to meet his account and recompense for what he presented in the first life, which was the journey of his test, and that the destination after the journey of trial in the worldly life is to the Creator Lord" (2). {The Day the earth splits open from them, hastening forth. That is a gathering easy for Us}: This verse is cited in inferring the possibility of Gathering after establishing the matter of Resurrection in the previous verse. In it is the mention of the image of people emerging from their graves, which is the earth splitting open from them just as plants split [the earth], in a not long time, then their gathering in the Place of Gathering, no matter how far their graves are from the land of Gathering, as mentioned in the hadith: «Then Allah sends down water from the sky so they grow as herbs grow» (3). In this is confirmation of the perfection of Allah's power and the comprehensiveness of His knowledge of all things, including the scattered, decomposed parts mixed with soil buried in the earth. It is a refutation of the polytheists' saying: {That is a distant return}.

book_title: The Quranic Objectives in Surah Qaf
text: {We are most knowing of what they say, and you are not over them a tyrant. But remind by the Qur'an whoever fears My threat}: This verse is the conclusion of the Surah, and it is a confirmation of what the Surah included of affirming Resurrection and Message, while turning away from addressing the deniers, and directing the address to the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him. It comprised three concise sentences: His saying, the Exalted: {We are most knowing of what they say}: contains consolation and reassurance from Allah Almighty to the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding the sayings of his denying people, and a metonymy for Allah's promise to His Messenger that He, the Exalted, will triumph for him against them, and a threat and warning from Allah to those who harm the Messenger with their words that He will take revenge on them and support His Messenger. For "He, Glory be to Him, informed that He is Aware of what His enemies say, and that implies His recompensing them for their words; since it is not hidden from Him, and He, Glory be to Him, mentions His knowledge and power to realize the recompense" (1). And His saying, the Exalted: {and you are not over them a tyrant}, contains a clarification of the reality of the Message and the reality of Da'wah (Call), and reassurance to the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, that he is not responsible for their lack of guidance; because he was sent only as a caller and guide, and not sent to compel them to believe. In it is confirmation that the caller is not charged with guiding his people, but rather inviting them and clarifying the truth to them is sufficient, to establish the proof and absolve responsibility. {But remind by the Qur'an whoever fears My threat}: This is the conclusion of the conclusion. In it is confirmation that reminding and remembrance revolve around this Quran. In it is teaching scholars and callers that the axis of their call should be centered on this Great Quran, and connecting people to it in all conditions, and in every field (2). For this reason, the Surah ended with it as it began with it: {Qaf. By the Glorious Qur'an}.

book_title: The Quranic Objectives in Surah Qaf
text: Conclusion. Praise be to Allah first and last. To proceed,, • The research has reached some results, including: 1 - That the Quranic Objectives are: Allah Almighty's intent from His speech, or the goals for which the Quran was revealed to achieve the interests of the servants. It is, in terms of independence, a relatively modern term. Its importance lies in being the key to contemplating Allah's speech, the Exalted, as Al-Shatibi said: "For contemplation is only for one who turns to the objectives". Also, knowing the Quranic Objectives regulates the methodology of interpreting Allah's speech, the Exalted, and preserves the Holy Quran from distortion and [incorrect] interpretation. 2 - That Surah Qaf is Meccan, and it is the first of the Mufassal Hizb, and the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to read it in large gatherings. The axis of the Surah revolves around addressing the denial of the deniers of Muhammad's message, peace and blessings be upon him, and what he brought of the news of Resurrection and Reckoning. 3 - Surah Qaf addressed several partial topics concerning Islamic Creed, all relating to addressing the subject of Resurrection and Message. Among the Quranic Objectives included in this Surah are: • Affirming the fundamentals of religion: belief in Allah, His angels, His books, His messengers, the Last Day, and Destiny. • Affirming the attributes of perfection for Allah and declaring Him free from what contradicts His perfection of deficiencies and flaws.

book_title: The Quranic Objectives in Surah Qaf
text: • Affirming the comprehensiveness of Allah's knowledge, including: affirming the doctrine of Allah's observation of man, His encompassing him from every aspect, and appointing guardians over him. • Affirming the perfection of Allah's power, including: clarifying the manifestations of Allah's power in creating the heavens and earth, in destroying the deniers, and in creating man. • Affirming Allah's wisdom in creating everything, and creating man. • Clarifying the Islamic religion's care for all aspects of human life, and giving a complete conception of his life which begins with his birth, passes through death, then ends with Resurrection and Reckoning, then the destiny to Paradise or Fire. • Consoling the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and the believers, and warning the enemies of the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, of the bad consequence of disbelief. • Revealing the conditions of the people of falsehood in inferring with corrupt reasoning, and the reasons for their denial of the truth. • Affirming the status of reason in Islam, and its non-contradiction with authentic transmission, and the call to use it to reach the truth, through thinking about Allah's cosmic signs, and learning lessons from the ends of previous deniers. 4 - The eloquence and inimitability of the Holy Quran, and among its manifestations: the way the Surah presents the central holistic and partial issues, which appear disparate and different -at first glance-, but upon contemplation we find them closely connected to the objective of the Surah. So scholars and callers should care for this Surah, Surah Qaf, by recitation and contemplation, and revive the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, in reading it in the Friday sermon, and in the Eid prayer,

text: and Fajr prayer, and not be content with reading verses from it (1); because compliance with the Sunnah is not achieved by partial reading, as the reading of the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, of the Surah was only because of what the Surah included of the most important objectives of the Quran. It is worthy for researchers to turn to studying the Quranic Objectives in all Surahs, especially those Surahs which the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to regularly read on different occasions, such as Surah Al-Qamar, Surahs Al-A'la and Al-Ghashiyah, Surahs Al-Jumu'ah and Al-Munafiqun, and Surahs Al-Sajdah and Al-Insan; for it aids in understanding the Book of Allah correctly, and returns with good to the Islamic society and the Muslim individual. And may Allah send blessings upon our Prophet Muhammad and upon all his family and companions. * * *
